review_preview: Along with my Better Half, and daughter, we had dinner here on a Saturday evening in October. Staying in the neighborhood, our hotel suggested Le Entretenida, and we‚Äôre so happy they did.Arriving without reservations well into the evening, we were greeted warmly and shown...
review_full: Along with my Better Half, and daughter, we had dinner here on a Saturday evening in October. Staying in the neighborhood, our hotel suggested Le Entretenida, and we‚Äôre so happy they did. Arriving without reservations well into the evening, we were greeted warmly and shown a table towards the bar area. The atmosphere and ambiance was very nice - brick interior, tables with space around them, and a busy wait staff looking after patrons. Across the night, multiple staff members checked in on us - which was well appreciated. We were well taken care of across the evening. After ordering some drinks, we were welcomed with an amuse-bouche. It was a delightful potato soup with hints of cream. Very nice. For mains, the ladies went with paella and I ordered the salmon tartar, as unfortunately they were out of the tuna tartar. My tartar was very fresh, well-prepared and delicious. Salmon was fresh and mixed with nice flavors. Really good. And then the paella came - and it disappeared quickly! The ladies loved it, and as it was my daughter‚Äôs first paella, we weren‚Äôt certain she‚Äôd enjoy. But she loved it. The rice was creamy, and the seafood portions good across the dish. Along with some drinks and dessert for the little one, our evening was very enjoyable. We liked the atmosphere, the wonderful service, and the delicious offerings. My compliments to the entire team. Madrid is fortunate to have La Entretenida. As Madrid is a wonderful city, we will return and La Entretenida will be one of our first stops. Thank you! Jeremy

review_full: Visited this restaurant with our family of 2 adults and 3 teenagers. 1 of the kids had a lovely feta cheese and olive salad while the rest of the family had burgers and chips. We asked for the burgers to be well cooked and they were perfectly done and freshly cooked in lovely gourmet buns with skin on fries. We visited in the early afternoon and about half of the tables were occupied. The waitress was very efficient and brought everything very quickly however she wasn't the friendliest which was a pity. The decor is very rustic which suits the vibe of the place and I'd say it's a great place to hang out at nighttime as they had a great range of beers and as I said the burgers are delicious. I do have one gripe however, the toilets! They could do with an overhaul!

review_preview: After ten days in Spain, we were looking for a quiet, comfortable and authentic spanish dinner; not just another tapas place.  We loved Tapas, but sometimes you want quiet, comfy and some comfort food.  The Westin concierge suggested this spot, and they were right in...
review_full: After ten days in Spain, we were looking for a quiet, comfortable and authentic spanish dinner; not just another tapas place. We loved Tapas, but sometimes you want quiet, comfy and some comfort food. The Westin concierge suggested this spot, and they were right in suggesting it; we loved it. The service was excellent, and the ambiance was warm, quiet and not "old world" atmosphere, but more brick funk. We split the artichoke as a starter, and I had the Paella with was outstanding. It was a short walk from the Westin, which is near the Prado.We didn't have reservations and went at 7:30. It looks like reservations might be needed later. You can't go wrong here.

title_review: High prices? Yes!!, Matching food? NO!!!
review_preview: Went there with my Spanish wife and two of our Spanish friends that are living in the area and wanted to do us a pleasure by inviting us to this fancy place. It seems to be a place for politicians and known people to see...
review_full: Went there with my Spanish wife and two of our Spanish friends that are living in the area and wanted to do us a pleasure by inviting us to this fancy place. It seems to be a place for politicians and known people to see and be seen. Well I didn't see anyone I knew, but didn't find that a pity. The variety of the dishes, was as usual in Spain, also good in this place. We went for some starters to share, salpicon de mariscos, tostada de tomate con anchois and pulpo a la gallega. The anchois were indeed between the best I have ever eaten, but I don't consider that an achievement of the chef, because they come canned or anyway else ready prepared. The pulpo was rather good as well, soft and tender and not the chewy stuff that you get in many restaurants. However the salpicon de mariscos (seafood), something with which the chef could have shown that he indeed knows how to cook, was a complete failure. The shellfish was way overcooked, hard and mixed with practically no herbs or spices and a usual vinaigrette. This was chewy and not nice. As a main dish we ordered a turbot for four that was prepared as a whole fish. This is in my opinion one of the best ways to cook a fish, with some oil or butter in the oven. And as every chef knows the risk of overcooking is not to big this way, but this chef managed to get it much to hard and dry. The turbot was presented just cut in four quarters, with skin and side bones. I have eaten in many Spanish restaurants all over Spain, but this is a very unusual way to present such a nice fish and not appetizing as well. In short two good starters, one bad and an entree that was spoiled by the lack of knowlegde by the chef. Seeing the arther high prices the bills didn't match the quality!! No wonder they lost their Michelin star!!

title_review: Highly overrated, terrible service and food
review_preview: I came here after seeing stellar reviews on both yelp and trip advisor. As an American traveler, these are my top two sources after exhausting recommendations from friends. Unfortunately, the glowing reviews of this place could not be further from the truth.I generally do...
review_full: I came here after seeing stellar reviews on both yelp and trip advisor. As an American traveler, these are my top two sources after exhausting recommendations from friends. Unfortunately, the glowing reviews of this place could not be further from the truth. I generally do not care about bad service as long as the food is good, but this place falls flat on both fronts. Besides making multiple basic mistakes which I can fully forgive owing to cultural differences and language barriers, the service here was completely unacceptable. The first dish that we were served came with a large piece of styrofoam mixed into it. When I brought this to the attention of the nearest restaurant staff, they immediately brought it back to the kitchen and replaced it. However, that was the extent of their effort to make up for this egregious error which could have easily gotten someone very sick if they weren't carefully looking at what they were eating. This might be acceptable behavior if this were a below average restaurant in the middle of a tourist center where nobody actually cared because business is guaranteed. However, because of the fact that this place is so highly rated, expensive, and tries to be a fine dining establishment, what happened with the service is absolutely unacceptable and unforgivable even considering language and cultural barriers (for the record I have enjoyed every other restaurant in Spain I've been to so far and had no problems with either of these issues). Besides the service, the food was awful as well. We asked for and ordered the recommendations but all the seafood was very mushy and over cooked. The mussels in the seafood mix were smelly, the octopus was over cooked and mushy, the shrimp had the texture of paste, and the sea bream came with bones which we explicitly asked multiple times about before ordering. Everything was also too salty overall. The only redeeming quality was the waiter bringing the bread. He was completely on point and the bread was fine. The wine was pretty good as well and was completely necessary to wash down the food.  Overall this place is very overpriced and the service is worse than the other restaurants in Madrid that are not nearly as expensive. If you are a visitor here I would actively suggest avoiding this place since there are so many other better options for dining.

review_preview: Anyone who follows my reviews knows we do Italian everywhere we go .. and this was one of the most disappointing Italian experiences we've had in awhile.In Madrid for Father's Day weekend .. also happened to be my husband's birthday. Our hotel recommended a...
review_full: Anyone who follows my reviews knows we do Italian everywhere we go .. and this was one of the most disappointing Italian experiences we've had in awhile. In Madrid for Father's Day weekend .. also happened to be my husband's birthday. Our hotel recommended a Vanvera so off we went. We arrived at opening -- overall, we found the service to be friendly. Chef did stop briefly at our table, but definitely did not pay the level of attention that I've read in other reviews. That high level of attention was given to people at tables surrounding us though. Started off with the burrata, which was promising. For mains, daughter ordered pomodoro, husband and I each ordered the spicy pork sauce, son ordered the truffled mushroom pasta. Ya'll know one important fact from reading my reviews: you can gauge the quality of an Italian chef simply by the quality of his basic pomodoro sauce. We didn't find anything redeeming in a single dish including the pomodoro. There was truffle in the mushroom sauce, but no salt, no follow through. (in fact, there was no salt or additional flavor in anything we ordered) The spicy pasta was well, spicy, by virtue of it being a spicy pasta .. no pork to be seen and the pomodoro was acidic. Tried to find redemption in the dessert; meh. Didn't even send us out the door with a limoncello. Two stars because we wouldn't return even to have dinner with friends.

review_full: We read great reviews about the place, and we recently moved into the area, less than 5 minutes away from home. All the staff spoke good English and made us feel at home, the owner/chef was charming and attentive, and the food was unfussy, beautifully prepared and presented, and delicious. My Romagnola style burger with shaved parmesan, sundried tomatoes and rucola was fantastic, My wife's tagliata was perfectly cooked and extremely tender. A nice and reasonable selection of Italian wines was an added bonus, the Etna Rosso was lovely! It's so nice to have a place like this nearby, we will definitely return......often!

review_preview: One of the best Italian restaurants in Madrid (maybe even THE best). You can find all the typical Italian dishes and a few more. Our favorites: burrata, vitello tonnato, huevo millesime and the carbonara (done the real Italian way!). Great place for truffle lovers! The...
review_full: One of the best Italian restaurants in Madrid (maybe even THE best). You can find all the typical Italian dishes and a few more. Our favorites: burrata, vitello tonnato, huevo millesime and the carbonara (done the real Italian way!). Great place for truffle lovers! The owner is Italian but speaks perfect Spanish and English - he is always proud and happy to welcome his customers, chat with them and make recommendations. Never had any issues with discounts and as returning customers we've always had 20-30% off the bill, no matter if we reserved with discount or not. We've been there many times and we will be coming back soon!

review_preview: Our flight from the UK was delayed by bad weather, so we walked into this restaurant in Las Huertas  late on a Saturday night, without a reservation, hoping it would be ok.We found it very welcoming, the food was good, (especially the squid) and...
review_full: Our flight from the UK was delayed by bad weather, so we walked into this restaurant in Las Huertas late on a Saturday night, without a reservation, hoping it would be ok. We found it very welcoming, the food was good, (especially the squid) and the service was very friendly.  The prices certainly seemed very reasonable.  We also had a lovely selection of desserts. The ambiance was quite laid-back. There is a big TV on the wall in one section of the restaurant. My only gripe was the waiter's insistence on leaving our wine and water way out of reach, but my opinion may have been coloured by the dreadful day we had had before we got there, which demanded immediate access to wine! If I am in Las Huertas again this summer, I would certainly consider visiting this restaurant again. .

review_preview: My wife and I just returned from a tour to Spain and the concierge at our hotel recommended this restaurant to us for one of our free nights. It was just a short walk from our hotel and turned out to be our favorite meal...
review_full: My wife and I just returned from a tour to Spain and the concierge at our hotel recommended this restaurant to us for one of our free nights. It was just a short walk from our hotel and turned out to be our favorite meal on our trip. Our server, Ali, was extremely attentive as were the other servers who were taking care of us (unfortunately I don't recall their names). We started out with grilled artichoke as an appetizer which was beyond delicious. My wife and I each had the grilled sea bass as our entree and it was probably the best I've had. It tasted fresh, very flavorful and was perfectly cooked. For dessert we split an apple tart which was also delicious. We had an after dinner liqueur, the name of which I don't recall. House wines are excellent....fish and salads fresh and beautifully presented... between ambiance and attentive staff we were enchanted. If you are staying in the Prado/Thyssen/El Sol area wander down Cervantes to find this gem.

review_full: A vAnvera was a nice Italian restaurant with quality service and food. I went on Thursday at 3:30pm and did not need to wait. It is a small and cozy atmosphere and the servers made me feel very welcome. I got the caprese salad, truffle and butter pasta, and the tiramisu to finish it off. Overall, the food was great and the chef personally came out to top the pasta off with the truffle. They even gave me some free light alcohol at the end to clean the palette. My only thing is that the truffle pasta could've used a little more garnish or something on the side to liven it up. The truffle mixed well with the butter, and I get what the chef was trying to do with the simplicity of the dish, but maybe some herbs or something would really make it a top notch dish. Either way, I would recommend this place to anyone.

title_review: Excellent meal, high quality, flavoursome dishes and an excellent wine list.
review_preview: A short walk from our Hotel we fortunately came upon La Entretenida in a quiet, narrow street.Not used to the Spanish eating so late we started our meal almost alone but by the time we left the restaurant was full. Perhaps getting there early as...
review_full: A short walk from our Hotel we fortunately came upon La Entretenida in a quiet, narrow street.Not used to the Spanish eating so late we started our meal almost alone but by the time we left the restaurant was full. Perhaps getting there early as a walk in guest assured us of a table. The staff were an eclectic lot and were all friendly and well trained to look after a similarly eclectic lot of guests. It felt like we were at a meeting of the United Nations; obviously the word had got around that this was a good restaurant. The beetroot and tomato Amuse Bouche was as tasty as soup gets, the olives, bread and pickled vegetables were excellent and followed by good sized mains of Sea Bass and suckling pig which were cooked to perfection. The strawberry and nougat ice-cream was a great finish to a fine meal enjoyed with a local white wine of excellent quality. The ambiance of the place was most embracing and the cost of the meal most reasonable considering the quality presented.

title_review: Excellent food, warm welcoming service and lovely atmosphere
review_preview: Found on TripAdvisor, we were happy to find this great restaurant. We were there early for Spanish dining and were warmly welcomed to this casual but elegant taverna and restaurant.  We were served hot and fresh bread and complementary soup shots and a bowl of...
review_full: Found on TripAdvisor, we were happy to find this great restaurant. We were there early for Spanish dining and were warmly welcomed to this casual but elegant taverna and restaurant. We were served hot and fresh bread and complementary soup shots and a bowl of olives and pickled capers. We had grilled artichokes, a special appetizer for the day, the best I have ever eaten. They appeared as beautiful as they tasted - the hearts and inner leaves trimmed, choke removed so that at they looked like a flower- with olive oil and lightly grilled! We also had grilled mixed vegetables- perfectly cooked with a red pepper sauce on the side. We also shared rice with shrimp- done in a pan like paella, but with a light tomato and seafood based stock, a very generous serving and delicious. We just had a glass of the house red wine which was quite good. We were too full to order desert, and were just having cappuccino but were brought a luscious sherry (chocolate- like flavor) and a small serving of desert that we just couldn‚Äôt pass up. When we came in the restaurant just had a few tables in use, but by the time we left it was packed. Everyone that came in received the same warm welcome. The food was beautifully prepared with sophistication and care. Overall a wonderful experience.

title_review: You won't leave disappointed, or hungry.
review_preview: I have been to this restaurant several times.  I am a Californian living in Madrid.  I bring all my visiting friends here after they have tried some Spanish food their first few nights.  Everyone loves it. It is basically gourmet pub food at a reasonable...
review_full: I have been to this restaurant several times. I am a Californian living in Madrid. I bring all my visiting friends here after they have tried some Spanish food their first few nights. Everyone loves it.  It is basically gourmet pub food at a reasonable price in a very comfortable atmosphere with excellent service. What's not to like? I usually have the Buffalo Chicken Burger (good piece of chicken breast in a tasty spicy sauce) or the Falafel Burger (which comes with a nice ranch type sauce). You don't have to be just a hamburger lover to love this place, although my friends who eat burgers rave about it. Mad Cafe also uses purple onions for the onion rings and they are fantastic. I appreciate the fact that they get the importance of having decent lighting and good music on. Having a great meal at "The Mad" allows you to continue your night without being hungry. It is in a great area to go for drink before or after dinner. Mad Cafe also has a nice bar, and it is a full bar, so you might find yourself just staying there!

review_preview: I really enjoyed this place. I've been to many "real American" places in Europe and this is the closest to US homemade food... with a touch of European sophistication (didn't try the foie hamburguer but they guy at the table next to me seemed to...
review_full: I really enjoyed this place. I've been to many "real American" places in Europe and this is the closest to US homemade food... with a touch of European sophistication (didn't try the foie hamburguer but they guy at the table next to me seemed to really enjoy it). The hamburguer was tasty and seemed barbacued (I like to see those iron burned lines on the meat, don't know how they do it). I personnally prefer them a bit thicker but still, it was really juicy. The cheesecake was the best I've tried in years. No doubt it was really homemade as the waiter explained. They have Root beer, which is quite unusual in Europe (I personally hate it, but I'm sure some people crave for it). Unfortunately they only have Bud. They're announcing they're gonna open for brunch on Sundays... my mouth is watering at the thought of egg and cheese biscuits, eggs Benedict, NY style bagels and so on...

title_review: Not as good as their Alonso Martinez branch!
review_preview: I visited Mad Cafe on Friday night after having a very good experience the week before in Mad Grill (situated in Alonso Martinez). I decided to visit this branch in Cava Baja as it is only a short walk from my flat here in Madrid....
review_full: I visited Mad Cafe on Friday night after having a very good experience the week before in Mad Grill (situated in Alonso Martinez). I decided to visit this branch in Cava Baja as it is only a short walk from my flat here in Madrid.  We arrived at around 8.40pm, 10 minutes after they had opened. The waiter asked if we had a reservation, to which I said no. He then contemplated giving us a table (the restaurant only had two couples that were seated), after much deliberation he said we could have a table until 10pm which we took. I was quite disappointed with this welcoming as in Mad Grill the week before the waiter was SO nice and accommodating!  Anyways, we ordered nachos which were really good! We then ordered cheeseburgers with fries. Fries were really good, we both ordered our beef WELL DONE, and we got well done on the outside and raw pink in the middle. This was a huge disappointment.  Our waiter was also a tad impatient, not attentive and could not crack a smile.  We then ordered a brownie for dessert ‚Äì this was superb! A proper brownie and the ice cream that accompanied it was good too! By this point we were given a much friendlier waiter who did smile and was very polite! He also asked us if we wanted a complimentary shot which was a lovely Spanish style Baileys! I also really like the atmosphere here too, full of couples or groups of friends..very pleasant!  All in all, the food was good (minus the mishap with the burgers). I would probably return just for the food as starter and dessert were very good! Shame about the service and the burgers not being well done.

I realized that this is one of the joints featured among the top 10 places for burgers in Madrid so I went on to try their bacon burger and their california one (I shared, it was not just for me). The place has an awesome environment; it's friendly and cozy and service is also good which makes the place stand out in the city. The food was amazing: the meet is cooked perfectly, the buns are really good, their fries are crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside and their Mad sauce is also really good. Prices are a 10 Euros average per person and the location is strategically close to La Latina metro station which makes it perfect for some drinks afterwards. Definitely a place to visit with friends to enjoy a good time.

review_preview: We found this restaurant from Tripadvisor before our trip to Madrid and decided to take a peek since it was only 10 minutes from our hotel. We got there just before 3 p.m on Sunday. The restaurant was only half full when we got there,...
review_full: We found this restaurant from Tripadvisor before our trip to Madrid and decided to take a peek since it was only 10 minutes from our hotel. We got there just before 3 p.m on Sunday. The restaurant was only half full when we got there, but when clock struck 3, people with table reservation started to flow in, and in the end we were quite lucky to get a table for two! So if you are to visit the restaurant in the evening, remember to reserve a table. The service was friendly and we felt welcome from the second we stepped into the restaurant. The place itself is a nice mixture of rustic, old bar and modern restaurant. They also feature nice collection of local and international beers, try them out! We ordered two bacon cheeseburgers that, to my mind, were good, but nothing special really. The meat was cooked well, but was left a bit tasteless. The prices are also a little high compared to the general price range of the city. All in all, the experience was good and I'd go there again if I had the chance.

review_preview: After all the praising reviews here on TA we decided to try this place out on our visit to Madrid. I'm really into good burgers and very keen to sample the local places wherever I go.We ordered chicken wings for starters and burgers for...
review_full: After all the praising reviews here on TA we decided to try this place out on our visit to Madrid.  I'm really into good burgers and very keen to sample the local places wherever I go. We ordered chicken wings for starters and burgers for mains. The chicken wings were surprisingly delicious and had a very authentic buffalo wings sauce on them. On the other hand, the burgers were not on par with the wings. The chili burger I ordered wasn't a burger with fresh chili or chili pur√©e, but instead a burger with some chili con carneish minced meat sauce on top. And the sauce wasn't even slightly hot, it had more of a bland tomatoish taste to it. I suppose the beef and the bun were of decent quality but the huge amount of the chili con carne pretty much overwhelmed everything else on the dish. I'm still contemplating whether I would've been happier with my dinner had I ordered the Buffalo Chicken Burger.

review_preview: We'd heard good things and were excited to try it out. We reserved (essential) for a Sunday afternoon at 2pm. Service was a mix of friendly and dry (we had two different waiters) but very efficient. The worst part of the experience was being seated...
review_full: We'd heard good things and were excited to try it out. We reserved (essential) for a Sunday afternoon at 2pm. Service was a mix of friendly and dry (we had two different waiters) but very efficient. The worst part of the experience was being seated by the staircase where I kept being bombarded by the smell of the bathroom fragrance spray. It was really unpleasant.  The menu is nice, prices are a bit high for what it is and I would've loved some non-alcoholic options that weren't sodas (homemade iced teas or lemonade, for example). But I had a decent glass of Rioja wine. The burgers were okay, cooked medium rare as we'd requested, and with a smoky charred outer crust (which I enjoyed, but my husband did not). The burger of the month had cabbage and Thai curry sauce-- the sauce was overbearing and would've been better with seafood. The fries were nice. For dessert we ordered the brownie, it was extremely dry, and the vanilla ice cream was just okay. 2 burgers, beer, glass of wine, one dessert and coffee for 39‚Ç¨. Not the best value in my opinion, given the overall experience. We were charged for an extra beer on our original bill, which they fixed since we noticed. Two shots of crema de orujo were given on the house, which is always appreciated.  Overall, we had a nice time but will be trying other burger restaurants in Madrid the next time.

Politicians and public figures come here as well. The restaurant is neither big or loud. It has a wonderful ambience.

review_preview: O"pazo is a polished, sophisticated restaurant with a superb seafood menu and a mature waitstaff.The dining room is elegant and comfortable. However, one can find seafood that is even more exciting served in somewhat more casual space with much more ambiance. O"pazo is the...
review_full: O"pazo is a polished, sophisticated restaurant with a superb seafood menu and a mature waitstaff. The dining room is elegant and comfortable. However, one can find seafood that is even more exciting served in somewhat more casual space with much more ambiance. O"pazo is the first restaurant we encountered in Madrid where jackets and ties were the norm. As a tourist, a little more color and a lot less pretension are what I look for. If one is eager to find great seafood in a very comfortable, yet chic, environment, another of my Madrid reviews would lead you there. I suspect that this review wouldn't be published if I were to provide the name. Although O"pazo doesn't miss a beat, I would look for music elsewhere.

review_preview: My daughter and I recently had a wonderful dinner at O Pazo in Madrid, which featured seafood as delicious as any I've ever had at Le Bernardin in NYC. We were greeted with rolls and a small plate of smoked salmon in lieu of butter....
review_full: My daughter and I recently had a wonderful dinner at O Pazo in Madrid, which featured seafood as delicious as any I've ever had at Le Bernardin in NYC. We were greeted with rolls and a small plate of smoked salmon in lieu of butter. I spied one of my favorite ros√© champagnes on the wine list at a very reasonable price so decided to splurge/economize on the Laurent Perrier at ‚Ç¨68. That went down real easy‚Ä¶We started by sharing a half portion of jamon iberico, which was not quite so luscious as that in the sandwich I had the day before at Mercado San Anton, and a plate of anchovies de Santo√±a, which were superb, particularly on the pan con tomates (like a tomato pizza) which the waiter recommended as an accompaniment. Next was the biggest indulgence of the meal - two grilled caribeneros de Huelva, like the sweetest, juiciest langostines - even the roe was delectable; the pair weighed in at 345 grams and cost a steep ‚Ç¨38 - cheap at twice the price. My daughter had sole (lenguado) as her main and I wild turbot (rodoballo salvaje) - wow! Why can't there be a fish restaurant this good in NYC? The only garnish was the very simple - and modestly priced at ‚Ç¨2.50 - green salad with onions. We finished by sharing fillas rellenas de crema (the best crepes ever, stuffed with a decadent pastry cream) accompanied by a glass of solera that miraculously transformed into three through the wizardry of our waiter. The service was wonderful throughout the meal; the proprietor helped me to order and directed the very efficient, slightly shy, but friendly young English-speaking waiter our way. The room is elegant and restrained, and the noise level so civilized that I could even hear my daughter across the table. We both loved O Pazo.

I would recommend the food but it comes at the cost of horrendous rude service!!

review_preview: First of all, I must commend waiter Ali for being so upbeat and for his willingness to please my requests. For me, Ali is the bait to come back and back many times when I am visiting Madrid. And now the restaurant. La Entretenida (the...
review_full: First of all, I must commend waiter Ali for being so upbeat and for his willingness to please my requests. For me, Ali is the bait to come back and back many times when I am visiting Madrid. And now the restaurant. La Entretenida (the name is from a Cervantes' comedy, I learnt this from Ali), is located at Barrio de Las Letras, in front of the Lope de Vega house on calle Cervantes, a 15 minutes walk after visiting El Prado or Plaza Mayor. The food is excellent Spanish cuisine. I usually have octopus or cod, both delicious. I recommend to come early, they are open all day. Sunday lunch is especially busy, with Madrile√±os chatting at the table for hours. Usually I don¬¥t make a reservation, but it¬¥s recommended after 7pm or on Sundays.

Well cooked, served warm, succulent en with a nice pimenton (paprika). Rarely it comes so good. The percebes (barnacles) , the langoustines and the red gamba's were OK but not special. However my main dish was hake, was excellent. A nice succulent, big piece, apparently cooked by an expert. This fish was the best I have eaten over the last couple of years. My wife's almejas (clams) a la marinera received a 7 out of ten from her. You will have some nice seafood in O'Pazo, but be prepared to pay a nice check as well.

review_full: Our party of 6 went here for dinner by way of a recommendation by the staff at the Melia Hotel. It's a few minute walk from the hotel. We arrived shortly after 9pm on a Monday night and were prompty seated at this upscale eatery. The restaurant was sparsely occupied at the time and we had our choice of tables. We ordered many dishes to share for our first course... hamon and cheese platter, calamari, and spinach salad. Each was tasty. They also comped us two appetizer plates... one was like octopus pizza, the other was melted cheese on tomato and bread. For dinner, we ordered three entrees to share... pepper steak, monkfish and hake. I liked them in that order. If you're a truffle fan (which I an not), you should get the hake. A bottle of red wine was a perfect compliment to the meal. Our waiter was very nice, helpful, and offered many suggestions. I can't comment on the cost, since it was a business meal and I never saw the check.

The food was quite nice and the waiter appeared embarrassed by the judgemental and pompous display from his, so called, senior. The food was OK. We ate a slightly over cooked but nicely presented spider crab and then ate a cooked sole. The level of competence was fine but not excellent. The tart de santiago was 'nice' and the chocolate mousse was OK, if a little too similar to a pre-made 'slam-it-in' and hope for the best restaurant shot-cut/time saver. The prices were certainly not reflected in the quality of the food or the unfortunate experience of meeting the 'head waiter'. But, we did have a laugh - at him. I've rated this place as average ONLY because our waiter was apologetic and went out of his way to try and improve the situation. The look and feel of the place was nice apart from the disgraceful head waiter.

review_preview: Don't go here if you don't like fish. But, if you do you'll be in heaven. Cockles and smoked salmon as amuse bouche with a copa of Manzanilla. Then salty, oily anchovies on a crispy tomato pastry, a bit like Pissaladiere. Followed by tuna cheeks...
review_full: Don't go here if you don't like fish. But, if you do you'll be in heaven. Cockles and smoked salmon as amuse bouche with a copa of Manzanilla. Then salty, oily anchovies on a crispy tomato pastry, a bit like Pissaladiere. Followed by tuna cheeks and ripe red tomatoes with mild raw onion and very virgin olive oil. Starters ended with prawns and lobster salad. The piece de reistance was a whole steamed turbot simply served with oil and vinegar but different from the oil used earlierl - somewhat milder. Finally ! an almondy toffee-ish praline. All accompanied by a beautiful bottle of Albarino. Service was brilliant too.

title_review: Great Food and Service After a Long Flight to Spain
review_preview: After a long overnight flight from Florida to Madrid, a short nap and a stroll around the Prado area, we asked the DoubleTree Hilton staff for a restaurant recommendation nearby. Thankfully they recommended La Entretenida, which was just around the corner. What a pleasant and...
review_full: After a long overnight flight from Florida to Madrid, a short nap and a stroll around the Prado area, we asked the DoubleTree Hilton staff for a restaurant recommendation nearby. Thankfully they recommended La Entretenida, which was just around the corner. What a pleasant and welcome surprise! It was a chilly and damp late December evening and the restaurant itself was a beacon of light in a basically non-commercial area nearby. The restaurant was warm and pleasant and the staff very friendly and helpful. But what is a restaurant without good food - and La Entretenida's was terrific. My wife and I shared the terrine of foie gras with figs which was smooth and creamy - some of the best that we have ever had; the spinach salad with pine nuts, apple, and cheese was also excellent; and the main course of hake grilled with garlic butter that was served as a whole fish and split at the table was outstanding. And the waiter recommended a glass of local rioja wine which was perfect for the meal - a totally wonderful meal with excellent and helpful service.  And we went back the next evening to try the meat courses, which were also great. I can't recommend this restaurant highly enough for service, atmosphere and food. Go - if you ever have the opportunity.

title_review: Quiet side street location that is a local's favorite- I can see why
review_preview: La Entretenida was recommended by the Double Tree staff for high quality food most frequented by locals. Couldn't have been more on target for my late Domingo afternoon meal. Not only did the restaurant have a very pleasant atmosphere, the service was top-drawer, extensive menu,...
review_full: La Entretenida was recommended by the Double Tree staff for high quality food most frequented by locals. Couldn't have been more on target for my late Domingo afternoon meal. Not only did the restaurant have a very pleasant atmosphere, the service was top-drawer, extensive menu, at mid-range prices. Management provided a couple of special additions to my choices, a sample of the vegetable soup just after I ordered my meal and a small tart after my dessert. Both were excellent. It was enjoyable to see locals of all ages, types and group sizes. Grandparents with their children and their grandchildren, This appears to be a local favorite on a side street near the hotel which is near Parliament. From beginning to end the restaurant delivered for value, taste, portion size. This establishment rates a return visit.

title_review: Less time advertising your chain of restaurants, more time on the food please!
review_preview: We visited La Entretenida, keen to try a new restaurant in the neighbourhood.  Unfortunately, we soon discovered that the restaurant was part of a chain of restaurants, both from the non-stop rolling advertising on the large TV opposite where we were seated AND by a...
review_full: We visited La Entretenida, keen to try a new restaurant in the neighbourhood. Unfortunately, we soon discovered that the restaurant was part of a chain of restaurants, both from the non-stop rolling advertising on the large TV opposite where we were seated AND by a mini brochure proudly left on every table. This chain has already bought two other restaurants around the corner, and again this was an experience of style over substance. The look, decor and uniforms do not compensate for weak food at inflated prices. The octopus starter was ruined by too much garlic, the San Pedro was tasty but dry around the edges, the steak tartar was dissappointing. The bill was too high for what we had experienced. There are better options for diners than this.

review_preview: Visited this venue on the recommendation of fellow travelers. If you are after an authentic performance of flamenco dance in an intimate setting (seats around 50) with passionate performers, then this may be the place for you. Located in a quiet suburban street near the...
review_full: Visited this venue on the recommendation of fellow travelers. If you are after an authentic performance of flamenco dance in an intimate setting (seats around 50) with passionate performers, then this may be the place for you. Located in a quiet suburban street near the Plaza del Torro de La Ventas, this place oozes passion. The performance (1 1/2 hours in total) consisted of 3 dancers, a singer and guitarist. In such an intimate venue there was no need for amplification. The dancers were fabulous and poured their heart and soul into their performances.  The Cafetin offers a meal but I wouldn't bother with that. It's pretty basic. Go for the music and dance and enjoy.

title_review: Great Flamenco but beware the pricing
review_preview: This tablao has great, authentic flamenco, although the guitarist plays a classical guitar with metal tuning pegs rather than a true flamenco instrument. Readers should be aware that the restaurant has no kitchen but serves a few tapas, which are quite good and the portions...
review_full: This tablao has great, authentic flamenco, although the guitarist plays a classical guitar with metal tuning pegs rather than a true flamenco instrument. Readers should be aware that the restaurant has no kitchen but serves a few tapas, which are quite good and the portions are large. I booked through Tripadvisor and TheFork, which promised a 50% discount. After initially being told that the cover charge was 14.50E, the waitress informed us that our cover would be 20E, to make up for the discount. We protested and held our ground and eventually paid 14.50. However, I felt that the establishment was trying to rip us off and the problem made the evening less pleasant. I still would recommend the place, but be sure you know how much you are paying ahead of time

title_review: Great food if you're tired of jamon!

review_full: Good food and a good selection of beer. After a few days in Madrid, my husband and I were looking for a meal that did not include paella or jamon and this cafe in the La Latina area was just what we needed! We both had burgers. While tasty, mine was more medium rare than medium well. Not being a fan of rare meat, I didn't eat the middle, rarer part, but what I did eat was excellent. My husband's burger was cooked as ordered. He especially enjoyed the Flying Dog Raging B!tch beer, which was a nice change from the standard Spanish beer you find elsewhere in the city. Overall, a great place to go, especially if you are American, have been on the road a few weeks, and are looking to eat something familiar for a change.

review_preview: On a girls weekend, we were desperate to see authentic flamenco and had been warned against going to flamenco shows in central Madrid due to high price and poor quality. My friend found Cafetin la Quimera on Tripadvisor and from the reviews, we decided to...
review_full: On a girls weekend, we were desperate to see authentic flamenco and had been warned against going to flamenco shows in central Madrid due to high price and poor quality. My friend found Cafetin la Quimera on Tripadvisor and from the reviews, we decided to try and book a table. We arrived first and were given the table nearest to the stage. It is a beautiful, small and traditional Spanish taberna with friendly, helpful staff with a real passion for flamenco music. For Euro 35 each, we had a meal, drinks and watched the show which was absolutely fantastic value for money. We ate before the show - the food was fantastic and very tasty. The show then started and we were blown away by the singing, flamenco, intensity and general atmosphere. We left in agreement that it was the best part of our Madrid trip. A must see if you want to experience a little piece of authentic Spain in the heart of Madrid.

review_preview: A lot of flamenco shows in Spain were in places that felt designed specifically for tourists. This place caught my eyes as different from the rest. From the closeness of the chairs to the small stage, to the cushions you sit on, to the sangria...
review_full: A lot of flamenco shows in Spain were in places that felt designed specifically for tourists. This place caught my eyes as different from the rest. From the closeness of the chairs to the small stage, to the cushions you sit on, to the sangria being served in clay cups - everything felt authentic. I sat on the side of the stage, so close to the dancers that I could see their sweat drip. There were lots of tourists, lots of locals, and we all got a wonderful show.

title_review: Authentic Flamenco Off the Beaten Path
review_preview: Our last night in Spain, we realized that the one thing we had not done was see Flamenco dancing.  We found La Quimera and booked online at the last minute.  It was a Sunday night and there was only one show, so we did not...
review_full: Our last night in Spain, we realized that the one thing we had not done was see Flamenco dancing. We found La Quimera and booked online at the last minute. It was a Sunday night and there was only one show, so we did not get the dinner option. But that didn't matter as we were mesmerized by the fabulous dancing and singing. There was one singer with a guitar and the seated dancers added percussion for whoever was performing. The establishment is fairly small, so everyone is seated close to the small stage and you feel the rhythm of the shoes tapping on the stage. The dancers (two men and one woman) were so passionate about their performances, it felt intimate and raw, not at all like a tourist show, but as though we had walked into someone's living room. The dancers were simply superb. We received a drink and appetizers with our admission. The show was just under an hour long, but very energetic and captivating. La Quimera is located in a neighborhood near the bullring (Las Ventas). There is a small playhouse across the street. We felt like we happened upon some local authentic culture in a hip Madrileno neighborhood. Highly recommended!

title_review: Intimate, intense, highly enjoyable Flamenco show
review_preview: My wife and I wanted to experience Flamenco and we picked this restaurant because it was highly rated and it was not far from the bullfighting ring, which we were going to visit before the show. Talk about the complete immersive Spanish cultural experience! We...
review_full: My wife and I wanted to experience Flamenco and we picked this restaurant because it was highly rated and it was not far from the bullfighting ring, which we were going to visit before the show. Talk about the complete immersive Spanish cultural experience! We bought the tix that included one drink, which seemed like the best deal going of the top 3 shows in Madrid. We were seated pretty close to the stage and it seemed like the small setting did not really have a bad seat in the house. The show started at 10pm and went on for more than 1.5 hours.  The Flamenco group consisted of a guitar player, a female singer and three dancers, 2 female and 1 male. All of them were excellent and brought a level of intensity to their performance that just rocked the audience. The energy and skills demonstrated by the male dancer were over the top. The show pace increases with intensity all the way to the end, it was exhilarating to watch and to listen to. Very soulful. A great night to experience Spanish culture. I booked the tix directly on the website. One note, when I tried to book in English the "book now" feature would not work, so I just went back to the Spanish version and website booking feature worked. Hey, it's Spain.

title_review: The place for authentic passionate Flamenco
review_preview: There are a number of flamenco shows in Madrid but after much consulting of Trip Advisor I chose Cafetin la Quimera near the bullfighting stadium even though it‚Äôs a bit out of town it was meant to be more authentic.  We travelled by taxi.  Afterwards...
review_full: There are a number of flamenco shows in Madrid but after much consulting of Trip Advisor I chose Cafetin la Quimera near the bullfighting stadium even though it‚Äôs a bit out of town it was meant to be more authentic. We travelled by taxi. Afterwards we just walked to the end of a street and easily picked up one to take us back. It was a small venue with a triangle stage in the corner. Dinner was basic but good quality. It consisted of the usual cheese and ham, followed by choice of main. I had moussaka just for something completely different. Pretty decent white wine too.  Besides we were here for the show and including dinner meant better seats. Our seats were great, one row back with a clear view.  The minimalist troupe absolutely looked authentic with a flamenco guitarist, a slightly possessed looking elder man, a rather handsome elder woman and good-looking young man and woman. The elder woman was the singer and she sounded soulful and passionate. The elder man was an amazing dancer and totally committed to his art, the passion almost consuming him at times. I was rather glad to be in the second row as the sweat was literally dripping off him with effort.  Flamenco is meant to be intimite and passionate and this show delivered on both accounts. We have booked to see a large "professonal " production in Barcelona so chose this as the other end of the spectrum. I'm glad we did both.

review_full: Visited Mad Cafe on the last day of my trip to Madrid. We were welcomed by the friendly staff who seated us quickly. They also served a range of American drinks such as Root Beer etc. The atmosphere was very relaxed, which was the opposite of what we expected after reading other reviews, but this may have been as we were in there before afternoon closing time. All in all, Mad Cafe was a lovely meal, made better by friendly staff and nice atmosphere

review_preview: I have lived in Madrid for a year now, and it is difficult to choose a favorite spot to eat. Mad Caf√© is my roommate's favorite (she LOVES burgers and fries). I have been here twice, once as a girls' night, and once on a...
review_full: I have lived in Madrid for a year now, and it is difficult to choose a favorite spot to eat. Mad Caf√© is my roommate's favorite (she LOVES burgers and fries). I have been here twice, once as a girls' night, and once on a date with my boyfriend. It is a fun place to have dinner because their burgers are delicious and big. Really good meat. Their carrot cake is also the best carrot cake I have had in Madrid. They have all kinds of fun beers, and their ambiance is great for a date. The nice thing is that it is right next to Cava Baja, where all the tapas bars are. So on a night out, my boyfriend and I went to Mad Caf√© for a big dinner, and then we partied the night away with friends in Cava Baja. One little thing was that I asked for my meat well done, and it was not. I am not picky about how my meat is cooked, so it was not a problem for me. But I know for some people this could be a deal breaker.

review_full: Mad Cafe is a small cafe with a few tables. There is only one waitress and she is quite kind though can not speak English. Me and my friend have been to Mad Cafe after reading so many good comments about it and wanted to try different burgers from their menu. We have tried 3 different burgers, nachos and a salad. To begin with, all the burgers were burnt. I wanted well done while my friend requested medium for the meat but unfortunately all were burnt. I do not remember the name but I tried the burger with duck breast on it and it was really bad. I strictly recommend you not to try this one. My friend liked his burger with extra cheese on it. We have also ordered nachos with guacamole sauce and it was really good on contrary to our expectations. We were expecting burgers to pop out but the best dish turned out to be the nachos. Keep in mind that portion of nachos is quite big, you will see how big is half portion in the pics below. Chicken salad was also bad because of the fish sauce on it. Yes, you heard me right, chicken salad had fish sauce on it and we did not like the combination of fish with chicken. You might like, I do not know. And about the prices, I do not remember the exact prices but burgers were between 8 Euros and 14 Euros and half portion nachos was around 5 Euros.

review_preview: Do not miss this place in Madrid if you like fish and seafood! My sister had found it in some webpage and reserved us a table. We took a taxi from our hotel, and while we approaching the restaurant, I thought she was mistaken, the...
review_full: Do not miss this place in Madrid if you like fish and seafood! My sister had found it in some webpage and reserved us a table. We took a taxi from our hotel, and while we approaching the restaurant, I thought she was mistaken, the area did not look like a place for a nice restaurant. How wrong I was! As soon as the taxi arrived, there was a person opening the car door and welcoming us to the restaurant. The atmosphere of the restaurant is modern and very pleasant. We were warmly received and directed to our table. We had a glass of Cava to start while studying the menu and the waitress telling us the recommendations of the day. We followed his suggestions and had a really wonderful dinner with sardines, mussels and big gambas, so good that my sister ordered one more shrimp because it was solo delicious. So seriously, if you love seafood, this is THE place! Wonderful evening!

This place is great for both lunch and dinner and i would highly recommend it.

review_preview: What a delightful and attractive venue! We dined at La Entretenida and felt welcomed and comfortable.The decor at this restaurant is typically Spanish with a strong rustic look through thick stone walls decorated by thin wooden shutters.The menu is both comprehensive and appetising....
review_full: What a delightful and attractive venue! We dined at La Entretenida and felt welcomed and comfortable. The decor at this restaurant is typically Spanish with a strong rustic look through thick stone walls decorated by thin wooden shutters. The menu is both comprehensive and appetising. The wine list equally provided ample choices and at reasonable prices. We were provided with appetisers of olives and bread, and choice of waters. Our entree was the grilled asparagus with Parmesan, which we shared. The asparagus were thick stalks and very nice. For our mains we selected the haute cuisine Cod fillet, with a thick sauce, and chicken with citrus and potatoes. Both meals were well presented and there were more than enough chicken pieces to satisfy any appetite. Our accompanying wine was a bottle of Spanish Verdejo which was perfect for our tastes. The service was friendly, attentive and prompt. A very enjoyable dinner and this venue is certainly recommended.

review_full: I definitely vote this restaurant as the best for sea food in Madrid. They received the products directamente from the Gallego harbor of A Coru√±a. It's as fresh as eating on the coast, yet a bit more expensive. You'll find everything you can dream of. As an appetizer you'll be treated to their own smoked salmon: the best I've ever eaten. Not too salted and absolutely delicious. If you're not afraid about spending, try their gigantic "cigalas a la plancha". Another great entr√©es: the "rodaballo al Jerez" or the huge "lenguado Evaristo". But don't worry, everything they serve is delicious, and if you have some doubt, let you guide by the maitre d'hotel. Dessert: canutillos rellenos. A must. The wine list is exhaustive and you'll find all king of excellent Spanish crus.

title_review: The best Filet of Sole I ever had
review_preview: I found this restaurant online as the reviews were great and booked it for our first night in Madrid and I am so glad we did. The maitre d' could have been friendlier, however, the waiters who served the food and drinks were amazing and...
review_full: I found this restaurant online as the reviews were great and booked it for our first night in Madrid and I am so glad we did. The maitre d' could have been friendlier, however, the waiters who served the food and drinks were amazing and so attentive. The atmosphere was classy, elegant and more on the modern side. The patrons were definitely upscale looking but not a snobby feel. Now to the food, we ordered the Filet of Sole which was probably the best Sole I have had in my life. Highly recommend. The bread, wines, appetizers were amazing and it was just a great experience to start off our trip. I loved the place and atmosphere and would definitely go back on my next trip to Madrid. The prices were not over the top either. It was such a great way to start our 1st night in Madrid. You can even make a reservation online - I wrote the restaurant and heard back immediately with a confirmation.

review_preview: This is a small venue (serves more or less 50 people max) but the flamenco show is quite dramatic and dynamic. There were 3 dancers, a singer and a guitarist, but I was mostly impressed by the dancing--extremely dynamic and breathtaking! We went on a...
review_full: This is a small venue (serves more or less 50 people max) but the flamenco show is quite dramatic and dynamic. There were 3 dancers, a singer and a guitarist, but I was mostly impressed by the dancing--extremely dynamic and breathtaking!  We went on a Thu without a reservation and we hardly got a table for 2 (only because there was a last minute cancellation), so do make a reservation ahead of time to make sure you'll get in. We paid 18 euros per person just for the show + a drink and we didn't have dinner in the tablao--quite frankly, I think the value is in the show, not in the food or service. Plus, it was way too crowded for my taste to have dinner during the show. Do go to see the performance--it's an unforgettable experience! The website for reservations and info about the venue is: www.tablaoflamencolaquimerra.com

review_preview: I visited this restaurant with my husband and two sons, aged 14 and 25. They all said that this was the best part of their visit to Madrid. The flamenco was fantastic and authentic. The singer had an incredible voice, no microphone...truly amazing. The dancers...
review_full: I visited this restaurant with my husband and two sons, aged 14 and 25. They all said that this was the best part of their visit to Madrid. The flamenco was fantastic and authentic. The singer had an incredible voice, no microphone...truly amazing. The dancers expressed their passion and it was a very moving experience to see an ancient art really delivered well, no lasers, gimmicks and flashing lights.... Remarkable.....very loud. The staff in the Cafetin were attentive, spoke English and made us feel welcome. My family are now flamenco converts... This is a must see experience. Slightly off the beaten track but well worth it.... And lots of cabs available afterwards.

In hindsight I'd have choosen a full portion of the asparagus, but otherwise perfect. As a main course we both had the lobster with potatoes (only served for two people). The lobster was erved with a unbelievably rich fish sauce. Normally I like my lobster served simply, but this was so good I was glad I made an exception. Deserts was also very good. My wife had a rich Tarte Tartin, while I had fresh fruit served with a frozen gin and topic mush!  Wine list is mainly Spanish, but offers good value. Simple wines are available for 10 Euro a bottle, while our excellent Rias Baixas was 30 Euro, Service was friendly and although our Spanish was is very limited this didn't cause a problem.  Downstairs the restaurant was very busy so I'm glad we ate upstairs. Persoanally I think food of this quality deserves to be served in a restauarnt that looks a little more impressive.

title_review: Beautiful decor, good food, not so good staff
review_preview: An overall good experience with beautifully prepared food accompanied with suitable wines. The sommelier was very professional and helpful in choosing wines. The same goes for the hostess; perfect hostess (friendly, approachable, professional and with a smile on her face constantly). However, the rest of...
review_full: An overall good experience with beautifully prepared food accompanied with suitable wines. The sommelier was very professional and helpful in choosing wines. The same goes for the hostess; perfect hostess (friendly, approachable, professional and with a smile on her face constantly). However, the rest of the waiting staff were a bit inpersonal and did not explain the dishes we got served properly. In a place such as this restaurant this is a perceived expectation from my side. Especially because I am very much interested in what I am eating there, here and everywhere. Regarding the food: The amuse with the potato foam was a very good piece to start off your taste buttons! The lobster salad was light, fresh and well-prepared. I had the sea bass (which was recommended to me) with artichokes, asparagus tips and noisettes. Beautiful!! (and I'm Norwegian(!)). We did not go for any dessert as we wanted to prolong the taste of the great fish.. I would visit this place for the fish, but considering the price level and ambiance; I believe there are other places just as good unfortunately, especially for young people whereas the average age in Goizeko was (this evening though) around 50-80 years. Finally, I had a overall great night with well-prepared fish and GREAT company.

We had a bowl of tiny chorizo and a bowl of dates wrapped in bacon (probably the best serving of the evening). There was some cured salmon with a tasty bit of cream cheese-like topping on a bit of bread, also good. A fresh and hot tortilla with cheese and potatoes arrived. It was good, but wasn't as tasty as the one from the night before. There also was a plate of several cheeses with mango jam. It all added up to more than enough food. The dinner and show cost 31‚Ç¨ and included a large glass of red wine. Nonetheless, we added another bottle for the table of five for an additional 20‚Ç¨, bringing the total to about $45 per head for dinner and a show. We took cabs to get here as it would have been quite a walk. A ten minute cab ride cost us a mere 10‚Ç¨. The dancing was certainly entertaining and demanded attention because it overpowered conversation. A good night and not very expensive for what we got.

title_review: Great Dinner, so glad we came in!
review_preview: As you can tell by my many reviews, I'm a huge steak fan and had been craving one while in Madrid.  Not knowing where to go and who would have my bone in ribeye available, I was lucky enough to walk by La Entretenida where...
review_full: As you can tell by my many reviews, I'm a huge steak fan and had been craving one while in Madrid. Not knowing where to go and who would have my bone in ribeye available, I was lucky enough to walk by La Entretenida where I saw the cuts they had available being displayed in the front window. Sure enough, there was my bone in ribeye! This one was even age dried which made it even better! The wife and I made it back to our hotel and called in reservations. For an appetizer we had fried calamari which was very fresh and delicious! For dinner my wife had a filet that cut like butter and had great flavor! I went with the bone in ribeye which was everything I could have asked for! Only down side was our side orders. We ordered rice and for some reason it was drowned in garlic. I love garlic and can eat it by itself but this was overboard! Other than that the meal was great, the wine selection was perfect and the service was spot on all night!

review_preview: Had been there with my wife while staying in the Wellington. We came in there just after 9pm being the first with another couple. 15 minutes later the doors opened and People flooded in occupying every table - so make sure you have a Reservation....
review_full: Had been there with my wife while staying in the Wellington. We came in there just after 9pm being the first with another couple. 15 minutes later the doors opened and People flooded in occupying every table - so make sure you have a Reservation. The menu itself wasn't the best looking, a lot of fine print you would rather see in a take-away. But available also in english. We decided to drop the menu and just follow the recommendations. We Chose three courses: red giant prawns a la plancha, bacalao (cod) with 2 sauces and Lobster Rice.  An "Amuse geule" was served with Bread and we had to mention that we would not go for meat or wheat. They reacted in seconds: there is gluten free bread and the "chistorra starter" was replaced by an absolutely delicate fish ceviche. This is an outstandingly positive reaction and I have never seen anything that quick in Spain before. The recommended Albarinho was amongst the best that I have tasted so far (and I am collecting them). Although I believe you can eat everything in there, the Loster was crunchy and sweet at the same time, while the Rice came in just as spicy as it should. You'll easily end up at 200 EUR or more, but it is woth every penny. With such a caring, quick and perfect Service plus outstanding Food and wine, I'd pay more if they just keep that Level.

I also chose the Brazilian acai smoothie which I absolutely recommend for a vitamin C hit!  Three of us, including drinks, ate for just under 50 Euros which I thought was great value.

review_preview: I am a regular visitor to Madrid and now most often stay at the Hotel Wellington.  I had not tried this restaurant in the hotel, as I assumed it would be far too fussy and "just another hotel restaurant".  I could not have been more...
review_full: I am a regular visitor to Madrid and now most often stay at the Hotel Wellington. I had not tried this restaurant in the hotel, as I assumed it would be far too fussy and "just another hotel restaurant". I could not have been more wrong! I needed a quick lunch booking for a Saturday in October and Goizeko was to-hand. The menu was wider ranging than I anticipated and while the extensive wine list was impressive, my guest and I were thrilled with the house white, a lovely Verdejo which was terrific value at 15 euros a bottle. I cannot wait to return - to both The Wellington and Goizeko, much much more than a hotel restaurant. It is most definitely a destination restaurant, as many people already know. Now I do as well.

review_preview: We stayed in the Wellington Hotel during our stay in Madrid. This restaurant is part of the hotel set up. The hotel is 5 star. Walking into the restaurant to make a reservation for an evening meal, two members of staff could not speak any...
review_full: We stayed in the Wellington Hotel during our stay in Madrid. This restaurant is part of the hotel set up. The hotel is 5 star. Walking into the restaurant to make a reservation for an evening meal, two members of staff could not speak any English; the third one had some limited English. You may ask why I continued with our reservation, but I did as we wanted something close to the hotel. The language problem was even worse when we arrived for dinner. Wine,bread, starters were words nobody seemed to understand. It was like being amongst aliens. We had far better understanding of English in some pavements cafes than in this supposedly 5 star place.Bread was like bricks so hard and tough. Main courses were good but very sparse.Fillet steak with some sauce and some slithers of vegetables but nothing else. Think 150 Euros for 2 with limited wine and terrible service because of their lack of being able to communicate other than in Spanish. Disappointing.

review_preview: This Basque-oriented restaurant associated with the Wellington Hotel in Barrio Salamanca, but with a separate entrance, is quite good. In addition to Basque specialties, there is a bit of Asian fusion on offer, with a Madrile√±o twist.I took a friend here for his birthday...
review_full: This Basque-oriented restaurant associated with the Wellington Hotel in Barrio Salamanca, but with a separate entrance, is quite good. In addition to Basque specialties, there is a bit of Asian fusion on offer, with a Madrile√±o twist. I took a friend here for his birthday and we both began with the real crab salad with avocado. Very good...I would have enjoyed a bit more avocado. He continued with a friend Merluza and Chiparones in Tinto (fried cod, accompanied by small squid in ink sauce). He gave me a taste, and the squid was amazing. Wish I had ordered the Chiparones! Not that I was discontent. I had a Meruzal a la parrilla, with a distinct smoky flavor, accompanied by a nice grilled red-pepper ratatouille. We shared a bottle of nice Chardonnay from Galicia. He had a chocolate tart for dessert, and I had yemas in some sort of cream...yemas being the interesting egg-yolk dessert famous in √Åvilla. He accompanied his dessert with an aguadiente over ice, and I had a spectacular Luis Felipe brandy from Jerez, which I'm going in search of once back in Pasadena! A very successful birthday dinner!

review_preview: First let me start by saying that goizeko is an elegant and classical place to have dinner, it is not a hip restaurant, do not except to see beautiful models at the door or anything like that but if you're looking for a great dinner...
review_full: First let me start by saying that goizeko is an elegant and classical place to have dinner, it is not a hip restaurant, do not except to see beautiful models at the door or anything like that but if you're looking for a great dinner with a perfect setting then you nailed it. The croquetas are amazing (both, jamon and truffle) the gambas con gabardina are terrific. The jabugo is amazing too, very well cut. As a main dish I ordered the pasta with a carabinero and it was very tasty and nice and my wife ordered some pochas, also delicious, and at the end we had a turron ice cream (best in Madrid) and a fondant and everything was great. Service was amazing too and the wine list very nice and not overpriced. Best place to have dinner in Madrid.

review_full: We went around 20:30 on a weekday. We checked before on internet if it was busy and had to wait for long. We arrived and found some empty tables for our surprise but some were already reserved.  Near the entrance there are tall tables with stools. We sat down on a table near the window. title_review: Absolutely superb food, service, ambience - could not fault it
review_preview: We often find that restaurants associated with traditional hotels are not stellar - this is the exception to the rule. The staff were amazingly good and very responsive given the fact that I have an allergy to bell peppers and don't like garlic very much....
review_full: We often find that restaurants associated with traditional hotels are not stellar - this is the exception to the rule. The staff were amazingly good and very responsive given the fact that I have an allergy to bell peppers and don't like garlic very much. They cooked new dishes without those ingredients in or where that was not possible, they offered up delicious alternatives. The ambience was lovely and there was a mix of all ages, from beautifully dressed teenage girls to ladies of a certain age with their elderly companions. The majority of the clientele were Spanish with a smattering of International diners. I would return to this restaurant in a heartbeat. Yes, it was fairly pricey, but in terms of a wonderful gastronomic experience, as ever, you tend to get what you pay for.

We were surprised with a delicious dessert of Basque pastry and chocolate truffles Our clams were the only thing not to our liking, this is not a good thing. The wine, a Granacha, was reasonable and excellent. The wait staff were first rate. By My standard I thought the meal was reasonable and excellent.

For main course we had the tenderloin of beef which was cooked to perfection with a side of green salad. As a dessert I went for the apple pastry which judging by the smile on the waiter I knew was a good choice. To accompany the food we had a bottle of the Rioja which was excellent. To cap it off the piano player in the lounge started playing which just added to the evening. A truly fantastic evening in Madrid and would highly recommend.

We wanted to have a late lunch after checking in at a nearby hotel. The host was extremely polite and welcoming. He promptly sat us at a coffee table with club chairs- not a dining table. I was a bit confused initially as I had told him that we were there for a meal, but the table felt as though it belonged in a club (more for drinks).Hey assured us that it was possible in fact to order food from where we had been sitting. Upon looking at the menu, we realized that the menu featured many different alcoholic beverages and snacks(appetizers), rather than actual food. Nonetheless, we decided we would just have drinks and then go elsewhere for a meal. We sat there for over 10 minutes, and no one came to take our drink order. The 2 to 3 servers we did see stayed in the back of the room attending to the other parties Who had in fact ordered from the lunch buffet which had closed already.  A server only came by when he saw us getting up and gathering our things to leave. When he approached us he said, "Do you want to order something?" We said no thanks, and left as we felt ignored and unwelcome.

title_review: La Rotonda is an awesome place to dine, have an afternoon coffee, or an evening glass of Cava or wine
review_preview: We had dinner here our first night in Madrid after a long day of travel, breakfast every day thereafter until today, when we did the Opera Brunch. It fit the bill wonderfully on all fronts!Under the beautiful, stain-glass dome in the center of The...
review_full: We had dinner here our first night in Madrid after a long day of travel, breakfast every day thereafter until today, when we did the Opera Brunch. It fit the bill wonderfully on all fronts! Under the beautiful, stain-glass dome in the center of The Palace Hotel, La Rotonda is an awesome place to dine, have an afternoon coffee, or an evening glass of Cava or wine. The Palace Hotel was built in 1912 and has been an institution ever since. Across the street from Spain's Congress Building and the Prado right on the Plaza de las Cortes, it's in the epicenter of Madrid. La Rotonda is open virtually all day. For breakfast, they do a huge hot and cold buffet, and will make you eggs any way you want them. The fruit is fresh and the coffee is hot! We did just breakfast and dinner every day in Madrid because we had such a great option for breakfast (eg no lunch required). Breakfast Buffet is open from 7am to 11am. On Sunday's, they do an Opera Brunch from 1:30pm to 4pm. Today, we had a beautiful Soprano and a tuxedo-clad Tenor, both with amazing voices that filled the dome and magically bounced around delightfully! They were accompanied by an excellent Pianist on a Grand Piano. Fantastic way to spend a rainy, cold Sunday afternoon in Madrid! The day we arrived from Seville, after a long day of driving and touring, we decided to grab a quick dinner at La Rotonda. My wife had a 4 Euro Dinner Salad, I had a 9 Euro bowl of Minestrone Soup, and we split a Spaghetti Bolognase for 15 Euros. Everything was delicous! Salad was fresh, the Minestrone outstanding, and the Spaghetti substantial, nicely spiced, and with lots of meat! It totally fit the bill! Most Hotels, even beautiful one's like The Palace, don't have a restaurant on-site of this caliber. Recommended.

title_review: Tremendously Flavorful Tapas and Great Service!
review_preview: Our party of four had to wait almost an hour for a table on a busy Saturday night   It was worth the wait.  The tapas were exquisite and the service was impeccable.  The "jabali" (wild boar) was the best I have ever tasted as was...
review_full: Our party of four had to wait almost an hour for a table on a busy Saturday night It was worth the wait. The tapas were exquisite and the service was impeccable. The "jabali" (wild boar) was the best I have ever tasted as was the "empanadilla Japonesa" these dishes are NOT to be missed. We also had two bottles of wonderful tempranillo from La Rioja. Even the coffee (served with a canister of brown sugar and a canister of white sugar for your choice) was wonderful. Likewise the desserts were scrumptious. We were compensated for the long wait by the wonderful food and quick, friendly service AND free chupitos of healthy proportions by the proprietor; I would dine here anytime and hope to return sooner rather than later.

review_full: I love this restaurant and always visit it several times when I'm in Madrid. Just back from another few visits in the evening and for lunch. It is always very busy at night time so you need to get there reasonably early and be prepared to wait for a table especially if you are in a large group. As I have always been part of a group of 6-7 friends we have always been happy to stand and have a few drinks whilst waiting for a table and most people who go there accept that this is what happens here. The atmosphere is always great and the food fantastic. We usually get a selection of things between us all to share. I was also here for lunch and had the ‚Ç¨11.50 deal which was for a starter, main course and dessert or coffee and a drink which is pretty good value though a number of places in Madrid tend to offer these sorts of deals. Will definitely be back again!

review_preview: I stumbled across a small square in central Madrid.  How could this be so peaceful when its just a few hundred yards from main roads, 5 minutes from the Palace and Cathedral?The square was bathed in sunlight on this September day and there were...
review_full: I stumbled across a small square in central Madrid. How could this be so peaceful when its just a few hundred yards from main roads, 5 minutes from the Palace and Cathedral? The square was bathed in sunlight on this September day and there were a number of cafes/restaurants with plenty of tables outside. This was a Sunday lunchtime and there seemed to be families and friends enjoying lunch, reading the papers...just relaxing! I then noticed the signs which confirmed that the establishments in the square (Plaza de la Paja) had worked together to stop buskers and other 'entertainers' disturbing the peace (no wonder it was quiet!). La Musa caught my eye - one of many restaurants - and I had a pleasant lunch. The menu (written in the form of a newspaper, with each 'article' giving different selections of food) gave a variety of tapas dishes. Remember you're in the heart of Spain, not a holiday resort, and many places only have menus in Spanish - so a phrase book (or translation app on your phone) will come in handy The tempura prawns were delightful, with thirst quenched by an ice cold beer. So the food was good - the location and atmosphere made the occasion. I'd love to go back there. Write down the address....you'd need to look for this place - its not far from anywhere but it's in a hidden corner.

review_full: I shared a fantastic opera brunch with my mother in this unique space within the Westin Palace Hotel in downtown Madrid. The stained glass dome that commands the restaurant is worth a visit: add a top quality brunch and decent opera live music, and the mix is a great deal at 77‚Ç¨ a person. Service was impeccable, a the food was a veritable cornucopia of delights, including seafood, suckling pig, top-tier iberico products, paella, pates, and a seemingly endless procession of patisserie. The opera program was performed by a pianist and two sopranos, visiting classic arias, ending in a fun La Traviata toast. Bottom line, grab your mom, or any opera lover and blow those hard saved euros in a magnificent afternoon, and feel like royalty for a few hours!

Microscopic potions, for example the first course which consisted of three things, one of which was bluefin tuna. There were three pieces of tuna about 3/8 of an inch square, a mouse would have gone away hungry. The staff were gracious, I asked to see the manager and explained our disapointment and asked him if he had tasted the menu. He said he was a vegetarian and so had not. He asked what he could do to remedy the situation which at this point not a lot. Next thing I know a Spanish gentleman a few tables away came over and thanked me for raising the issue with the manager, he said he could not have agreed more with my assesment and the meal was a disaster, not representative of Peruvian cusine at all. We ended up chatting with this man and his wife at length which was the high point of the evening then we left hungry.
